awd_titl_txt: RUI: Role of Mechanical Forces Axial Torsion and Flexure in Chick Embryos
awd_abstract_narration:
The developing chick embryo undergoes a series of complex shape changes called morphogenesis. Although the genetic and molecular aspects of morphogenesis are well-studied, scant attention is paid to the mechanical aspects. In particular, the driving forces behind the dramatic shape changes during embryo development are poorly understood. This project considers two often-overlooked, but critically important shape changes that occur during early embryo development: (1) body flexion, which curves the initially straight embryonic body axis and (2) body torsion, which rotates it. Flexion and torsion are necessary for proper development of important organs such as the heart. The forces driving flexion and torsion are not currently known and understanding them is the goal of this project. This research will train numerous undergraduate students in all aspects of research. Science outreach, particularly to under-represented minorities, is another critical aspect of this project. It includes a formal collaboration with Union College?s Science and Technology Entry Program, which introduces underrepresented minority and economically disadvantaged students in grades 7-12 to STEM fields. 

A combined experimental and computational approach is used to determine the forces driving flexion and torsion. The chick embryo is used as the experimental model. Light microscopy and optical coherence tomography  will be used to qualitatively and quantitatively characterize flexion and torsion in the developmental stages under consideration. Atomic force microscopy will be used to probe the mechanical environment of the regions undergoing flexion and torsion. And chemical and biomechanical perturbations will be used to study these processes further. The finite element method will be used to develop the computational model which will be validated by comparing experimental and model-predicted global and local shape changes. The validated model will be used for hypothesis testing to determine the forces driving flexion and torsion.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed to study flexion and torsion during early embryo development. We used the chick embryo as our experimental model; we also used computational modeling. Due to flexion, the initially straight embryo body is bent into a curved shape. Torsion occurs simultaneously and twists the embryonic axis. Together, flexion and torsion give rise to the familiar fetal position seen in avian and mammalian embryos. The following are the primary project outcomes for Scientific Merit:

(1) We were able to use tools from the mathematical discipline of Differential Geometry to quantify embryonic flexures under both normal and abnormal developmental conditions.
(2) We were able to show that embryonic membranes do not play a major role in the progression of flexion and torsion.
(3) Results from Finite Element Modeling and Chemical Perturbations indicate that differential growth could lead to experimentally observed shape changes.

This was an RUI project and training of undergraduate students was a top priority. Numerous undergraduate students were trained despite significant obstacles imposed by the pandemic. The following are the primary project outcomes for Broader Impact:

(1) Undergraduate Research is a core strength at Union College - we do not have any graduate students or graduate programs. Numerous undergraduate students were trained in all aspects research including (but not limited to): working in a wet lab environment, literature review, imaging studies, and keeping records. Undergraduate students were also trained in the use of sophisticated instruments including Atomic Force Microscopy (AFM) and Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT).
(2) We recruited and trained a diverse group of students with significant participation from women, underserved populations, and international students.
(3) Outreach to the local community was a key component. We hosted groups from local area high schools and separately, the PI made a presentation on the research in his son's middle school.
(4) Almost all of the students involved attended a major conference, including the Biomedical Engineering Society (BMES) annual meeting.
(5) Many students were able to leverage the research training to secure fully funded Ph.D. program admissions at excellent graduate schools.
